entry.title: Re: VA01 Line Item Numbering Increment Logic
entry.content:
Yeah i included my logic there but for some reason, it was not being triggered.

Here is the steps when i create a line item:

VA01, create from a reference

Grandparent line item is 20000

Create parent line item and input the "20000" in the HL item level(VBEP-UEPOS). 20800 was created and the numbering was expected.

Create a child line item and input the "20800" in the VBEP-UEPOS field. 21600 line item was created instead of my desired numbering or increment of +1.

entry.title: How to Learn SAP BW/4HANA and Get Certified
entry.content:
How to Learn SAP BW/4HANA and Get Certified

SAP BW‚àï4HANA offers a managed approach to data warehousing. This means that prefabricated templates (building blocks) are offered for building a data warehouse in a standardized way.

So how can you become proficient in SAP BW/4HANA?

The SAP Certified Associate - Data Engineer - SAP BW/4HANA certification verifies that you possess the core skills required in the role of a Data Engineer in the SAP BW/4HANA area. It proves that you have an overall understanding and in-depth technical skills to participate as a member of a project team in a mentored role. The certification is recommended as an entry-level qualification.

The following diagram shows the Data Engineer role responsibilities compared with the Data Analyst/Data Scientist role.

 

 

Online Self Study

For online self study, you can use the learning journey Exploring SAP BW/4HANA to prepare for the certification.

In this learning journey, you build your knowledge step-by-step with online courses, containing explanations using texts, videos and exercise simulations.

The following online courses are needed to prepare for the certification:

  • Getting Started Building an On-Premise Data Warehouse using SAP BW/4HANA
  • Creating Queries in SAP BW/4HANA
  • Implementing a Data Warehouse Using SAP BW/4HANA
  • Implementing Modeling Scenarios in SAP BW/4HANA
  • Implementing Data Provisioning in SAP BW/4HANA
  • Implementing Authorizations in SAP BW/4HANA

Instructor-led Classroom

As an alternative, you can attend instructor-led classroom trainings (on-site or virtual), where you can also work through lots of exercises on a provided SAP system.

The following instructor-led trainings are needed to prepare for the certification:

  • BW405: SAP BW/4HANA Query Design and Analysis
  • BW410: SAP BW/4HANA Data Warehousing
  • BW430: SAP BW/4HANA Data Modeling
  • BW450: SAP BW/4HANA Data Acquisition
  • BW465: SAP BW/4HANA Authorizations

Hands-on Practice

If you want to practice outside the setting of a classroom training, SAP Practice Systems offers to practice using the similar exercises that are used in the instructor-led class. To access SAP Practice Systems you need a subscription to the SAP learning portal: (https://learning.sap.com/).

Do you want to use practice systems? Just click below:

https://learning.sap.com/practice-systems?page=1

 

Live Sessions

In addition to courses and practice systems, the SAP Learning portal offers live sessions that are useful for learning guidelines, ask questions, and deepen your knowledge on specific topics. These sessions are delivered by subject-matter-experts (SMEs), either from SAP Training, SAP Partners or other experts at SAP such as Product Managers.

The sessions come under five categories:

  • Get Started
  • Expert Deep Dive
  • What's New
  • Get Certified
  • Stay Certified

Some of the live sessions are available for free, some require a subscription. Just click below to explore the live sessions:

https://learning.sap.com/live-sessions?page=1

 

Certification Exam

When you feel prepared enough, it's time to take the certification exam.

On this topic, there is some news. SAP is moving its certification model towards practice-based exams which will replace traditional theoretical/knowledge-based exams (multi-choice questions), starting January 1st 2026. Some pilot exams are already available since the beginning of November 2025.

Community

We are looking forward to getting your feedback on these resources aimed at getting your level higher in the area of SAP BW/4HANA. Please feel free to use this new community and connect with us and other learners. Also let us know about topics you would like to have covered in future live sessions, so that we can make our content even more suited to your needs.

Happy learning with SAP!

Eric Kuijvenhoven

entry.title: Enhance security with new CQCs
entry.content:
We are excited to introduce a new/expanded service from SAP Enterprise Support that ensures the security and high availability of your SAP solutions. The Continuous Quality Check "Security Optimization" is designed to thoroughly analyze, verify, and enhance the security of your SAP cloud solution. We have three (3) workstreams available covering SAP S/HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP SuccessFactors and SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP).

After a detailed security analysis, the service will provide recommendations to improve your configuration and authorizations. For this pilot delivery, SAP will assign a dedicated expert to guide you through the process.

Upon completion of the service, you will receive a comprehensive report that includes an executive summary, detailed findings, and recommendations to mitigate risks and enhance your security posture. You can expect to receive the results approximately one week after the session.

If you wish to participate, please ensure you meet the following prerequisites:

  • Grant remote access to your SAP cloud solution to SAP.
  • Be available to collaborate with SAP delivery experts in multiple remote sessions within a mutually agreed 4-6 week timeframe in Q1 2026.
  • Be willing to provide open and honest feedback on the service content and respond to our survey requests.
  • Please note that all workstream activities must be completed by March 15, 2026.

We look forward to working with you and helping you enhance your SAP security.

Contact us today to get started.  
esac@sap.com

Additional information about the SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council can be found here.

entry.title: Re: VA01 Line Item Numbering Increment Logic
entry.content:
Why your MV45AFZZ logic did not trigger because, USEREXIT_MOVE_FIELD_TO_VBAP is called when fields are moved from screen to VBAP, but item number assignment is already handled earlier by SAP standard routines. The debugger won‚Äôt stop there for item number increments because the system calculates the next item number in SAPMV45A ‚Üí FORM VBAP-POSNR handling before your exit. That is why you saw 21600 instead of your desired +1 increment ‚Äî the standard increment logic overrode your custom code.

The correct enhancement spot is not MV45AFZZ alone. You should look at USEREXIT_NUMBER_RANGE or USEREXIT_NEW_ITEM_NUMBER in MV45AFZZ, or the BAdI SD_SALES_ITEM (method ITEM_NUMBERING). These are specifically designed for controlling item number assignment.

But you should be careful in this custom validation because, SAP expects item numbers to be unique and in increments that allow later insertions. Using +1 increments may cause conflicts if users insert new items later.

Test thoroughly in scenarios like copying orders, creating returns, or adding items mid-sequence.

entry.title: BExWeb Migration 101: Migrate from BExWeb to SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
BExWeb Migration 101:
Migrate from BExWeb to SAP Analytics Cloud

The BExWeb Migration can be a complex and time-consuming task for companies. However, the good news is that migrating the reports themself is often quite simple. And that is what this blog is all about! It intends to share my experience of migrating reporting from BExWeb to Sap Analytics Cloud (SAC) and answer:

  • What does migration mean,
  • What are relevant BExWeb objects to migrate,
  • Ways of migration and when to use them

In addition, it will offer simple guides for these migrations.

This blog will not discuss why to choose the SAC to migrate to or why to migrate at all. It will neither delve into the differences between these two tools, nor the strengths and weaknesses of the SAC, including its limitations or features and not describe the perks the migration will bring.

 

What does migration mean?

There are various definitions what migration could mean in this context. In this blog it is seen as completed once the end user can consume and access information entirely from SAC instead of BExWeb. This includes not only to create a duplicate in SAC but also connect said object to their consumers. As an example, replacing BExWeb links in the centralised reporting library by the newly generated SAC ones.

 

What are relevant BExWeb objects to migrate?

Figure 1: Categorize objects used for Reporting in BExWeb

The most basic kind of object represents in the BExWeb reporting are Queries without modification in BExWeb. These reports open the default view of a query. This means that BExWeb only views the query but not alters it.

In contrast to opening a Query in the default view, Bookmarks are queries which were altered in BExWeb to fulfil a reporting need by variating the view (e.g. dimensions, measures or filters), the formatting (e.g. scalling, conditional formatting) or variables. Based on who created the Bookmarks, one can differentiate between globally and locally used Bookmarks. On the one hand, global Bookmarks are created centrally and can be used by several users. Locally used Bookmarks, on the other hand, are created by end user, are mainly used by themselves, and only persist for a limited time. This differentiation is solely used for specifying the categorization of BExWeb objects in this blog, as from a technical point of view they do not differ.

Another kind of objects used in BExWeb are scheduled Broadcastings, which can also be migrated. Broadcasting refers to the possibility of distributing information found in a BExWeb Report to other users. Typically, this is done when a BExWeb Report is exported as e.g., an Excel of PDF file and sent to a colleague via email. When this process is automated with preset settings and for a defined time it is called scheduling. As scheduled broadcasting often distributes important information to many users, it is to be considered for migrating when the remaining lifetime of a scheduling exceeds the usage of BExWeb in the company.

Templates used in BExWeb are a special topic, as the ways they are used can differ widely. Their uses can range from changing the context menu in BExWeb Reports, to adding groupings to free characteristics, to combining these features and many more possibilities. Therefore, no specific details will be given in terms of migrating Templates, only assistance will be provided:

  1. Get to know the Template:
    • Open the transaction SE38 (‚ÄúABAB Editor‚Äù)
    • Open the report RS_TEMPLATE_MAINTAIN_70
    • Enter the Template
    • Note: to find all differences it can help to compare the Template with a ‚ÄúBase-Template‚Äù

  2. Categorize findings:
    • Does the Template change the grouping of free characteristics?
    • Does SAC automatically offer the feature the Template provides?
    • Are the Template‚Äôs features rebuildable in SAC?

  3. Migrate the Template:
    • Groupings can be solved with an SAC Model and manual grouping of the dimensions
    • If the features are automatically migrated, this step is already completed
    • If they cannot be directly migrated, challenge the importance of these feature. In case they are relevant, workarounds are often available to address these challenges.

Similar to Templates, Report-Report-Interfaces are a special topic in the migration process. However, the good news is that they are maintained in SAP BW (Transaction RSBBS). There, they are automatically ‚Äúmigrated‚Äù to SAC if the system is maintained correctly and the type of Report-Report-Interface is supported by SAC. To provide an example: Jump to Query or Jump to URL are supported. However, when parametrization is required when jumping to URLs, it needs to be implemented by using Business AddIns.

 

Ways of migrations and when to use them

There are many options for migrating BExWeb objects to SAC and various means to categorize these kinds of migrations. It is important to note that all migrations must be performed manually by recreating BExWeb objects in the SAC. This blog will define and explain four different ways to migrate, as shown in the following:

Figure 2: selected Options for Migration

In summary, the simplest form of migration, is the migration as a Live-Connection, is recommended for Queries. It requires barely any migration effort and does not need to be maintained. For Bookmarks, the previously mentioned differentiation between globally und locally used ones becomes relevant again. It is recommended to migrates as a Shortcut for locally used Bookmarks, as the lifetime limitations of this option are not significant for them. To guarantee their persistence globally used Bookmarks should be migrated as an Insight. This is also recommended for scheduled Broadcasting as scheduling requires an artefact in the SAC, like an Insight or a Story. If the sole purpose of the artefact is scheduling, an Insight is sufficient, and building a story is unnecessary. In general, creating Stories as a mean of migrating BExWeb Reports is not recommended, as most use cases can be covered with SAC Data Analyzer. In certain cases, gaps in the SAC Data Analyzer can only be resolved by creating a Story, this should be considered and kept in mind. Creating a story offers a broad range of features, hence, making it a valuable migration option under the right circumstances.

In the following, a more practical approach will be taken by providing a stey-by-step guide on how to migrate as a Live-Connection, a Shortcut and an Insight. Due to its complexity, migration as a Story will not be covered in this blog.

 

How to migrate as a Live-Connection

In order to migrate as a Live-Connection, open the SAC Data Analyzer with any query. To speed up the process, save yourself one link to use it as a reference.
Once the connection is created, enter the technical query name which should be migrated under ‚ÄúdataSourceName‚Äù in the URL (1). In case a SAC model is used, enter the model ID instead of the technical query name. Alternatively, both can be open through the SAC GUI within the Data Analyzer Menu (2).
Once the URL has been adapted, the migration as a Live-Connection is successfully completed. Remember to save the link and update it wherever the BExWeb link was previously saved in you company.

Should the query be unknown, the required information can be accessed via the BExWeb URL under ‚ÄúQUERY‚Äù or in the menu ‚ÄúInformation‚Äù under ‚ÄúQuery Properties‚Äù in BExWeb. Additionally, if a Template is used, this information can be found in the BExWeb URL too, under ‚ÄúTEMPLATE‚Äù.

Figure 3: Migrate as a Live-Connection

 

How to migrate as a Shortcut

The beginning of this approach is similar to the migration as a Live-Connection. Start by opening the query which was used in the BExWeb Reporting in the SAC Data Analyzer or the model which is based on this query. Afterwards, alter the query in the same way it was modified in the BExWeb Bookmark. To ensure nothing is overlooked, keep these three types of variation in mind:

  • Variations in the View
  • Variations of Formatting
  • Variations of Variables

For variations in the view, check the Bookmarks view and whether columns and rows differ from the default view. Keep an eye on used dimensions, measures, filters, and the current sorting as well as calculated measured created in BExWeb. In order to access variations in formatting, check the overall look and pay attention to small details, such as decimal places, scale, and signs. To check variations of variables, open the prompt in the Bookmark and default view and compare these two.

Once all necessary adaptions are finished, press the ‚ÄúShare‚Äù-Button in the Data Analyzer (1), click on ‚ÄúCreate Shortcut Link‚Äù (2), and proceed to create a Shortcut. Once all steps are completed, a new URL will be generated which link to the Shortcut. Once again, remember to save the link and update it wherever the BExWeb link was previously saved in you company.

Figure 4: Migrate as a Shortcut

 

How to migrate as an Insight

Similar to the previous approaches, start by opening the SAC Data Analyzer. Should any alterations from the default view be necessary, follow the steps described in the previous chapter.
Once the view is correct, save the Data Analyser as an Insight by pressing the ‚ÄúSave‚Äù button (1). This will open a menu where you can navigate to the correct folder the Insight should be saved in. Align with your company‚Äôs standards to choose the correct folder and save the file. You have now created a new SAC artefact, which can be used to exchange the BExWeb predecessor. When reopening the Insight, users with the according authorizations can save changes or save it as a new Insight.

Should you wish to migrate a scheduled Broadcasting, additional steps are required.
Click on the ‚ÄúShare‚Äù button (2) where now the option ‚ÄúSchedule Publication‚Äù (3) is available. Choose this option to open the scheduling settings. If the correct settings for the new scheduling are unknown, access the settings of the BExWeb scheduling with the SAP BW transaction ‚ÄúRSRD_ADMIN‚Äù. This transaction provides important scheduling information, such as the technical name of the query, the format used (e.g. PDF), and the scheduled time. Additional information can be found by using the SAP transaction ‚ÄúSOST‚Äù. Among other things, the status of send-out E-Mail is monitored as well as all users which receive the broadcast.

Once all necessary information has been acquired, the scheduled Broadcasting can be set up. Choose a name, specify the email content, select the format for sending the information, add the recipients, set the start and end dates, and define the recurrence pattern (hourly, daily, weekly, or monthly). In the next quarterly update, it will be possible to set the pattern on working days only. By clicking on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù the migration of the scheduled Broadcasting is completed.

Figure 5: Migrate as an Insight

 

Conclusion

In conclusion, migrating from BExWeb to SAC is quite straightforward and can, in theory, be carried out quickly. However, significant complexity is added when the reporting is not standardized, highly customized to fulfil company needs or through the sheer number of reports. It requires establishing a precisely defined scope of the migration, including gathering all necessary information, dealing with complex objects like Templates, or implementing workarounds for SAC gaps. Overall, migrating from BExWeb to SAC is a manageable and important step toward the future of reporting. Although some features may no longer be included, this step creates plenty new opportunities.

entry.title: EWM - One warehouse order per manufacturing order while staging from different storage types
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts,

I have the following situation. I have a advanced production integration with a staging scenario via PWR‚Äôs (Production Material Requests). In my supply area I am using the staging method for ‚ÄúSingle-Order Staging‚Äù.  The warehouse tasks for staging are being created by a job via the transaction /SCWM/STAGE. All of this works perfectly fine, but I have the following request.

Per manufacturing order there should only be one warehouse order, containing all warehouse tasks. I‚Äôm aware, that in the standard a new warehouse order is created as soon as the stock must be picked from a different storage type (because of the activity area). So the warehouse order creation rule sorts by the storage type or the according activity area. As you can see, for every new storage type, a new warehouse order is created.

What I need is, that no matter from which storage type the staging happens, as long as it‚Äôs for the same manufacturing order only one warehouse order is created. This way the confirmation via a scanner (RFUI) is more convenient. So in this example only one warehouse order ‚Äú2002254‚Äù contains all warehouse tasks.

I found the following settings where I hoped it might work:

SIMG -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Cross-Process Settings -> Warehouse Order -> Define Sort Rules for Warehouse Tasks:

I also tried the RDOCID, but it didn‚Äôt work.

SIMG -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Cross-Process Settings -> Warehouse Order -> Define Limit Values for the Size of a Warehouse Order

SIMG -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Cross-Process Settings -> Warehouse Order -> Overview of Creation Rules for Warehouse Orders:

For testing I simply put the WOCR into my warehouse process type:

The system finds my WOCR, but It combines all picks from one storage type together and not by the manufacturing order:

As you can see in the WO logs, the system uses the WOCR but only according to the storage types:

Is there something I am missing or are these settings not suitable for my scenario? Are there any other ways to accomplish this?

entry.title: Issues with Joule AI on SAP SuccessFactors Test Instance & Customization of AI Instructions
entry.content:
Issues with Joule AI behavior and customization options

We have tested several times the Joule  Joule AI implemented on our SAP SuccessFactor test instance, and we are repeatedly facing error messages such as:

  • ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, but I can‚Äôt‚Ä¶‚Äù

  • "I am unable to ..."
  • ‚ÄúThis action is not available at the moment‚Äù

(see screenshot attached below)

Could you please explain why these messages appear? We would like to understand whether this is related to system configuration, authorizations, current limitations of Joule, or the test environment.

In addition, we would like to know if it is possible to customize Joule‚Äôs instructions or responses.
For example, when asking ‚ÄúHow can I create a job requisition?‚Äù, Joule provides the standard SAP SuccessFactors procedure, whereas we would like it to return our internal company process instead.

Is it possible to modify or configure Joule so that it uses company-specific procedures or documentation rather than the default SAP SuccessFactors guidance?

Finally, could you please let us know how to formally submit or escalate enhancement / evolution requests related to Joule AI (e.g. new functionalities, customization capabilities, or improvements)?

Thank you in advance.

entry.title: Changing the accounting Principle - Not able to delete treasury transaction
entry.content:
Let me explain my issue in detail. After quite some time, we found that the principal accounting is wrongly assigned to the leading ledger and the non-leading ledger. The leading ledger is assigned to the local GAAP, and the non-leading is assigned to IFRS.

Which we need to change it to another way. Leading ledger to IFRS and non-leading ledger to Local GAAP.

However, a few transactions have been posted in the Finance and Treasury Modules.

We have run the reset Transaction Job, and it was successful. But this program did not delete the treasury transaction, which is now stopping us from changing the accounting principle to the ledger and non-ledger.

FYI there is nothing yet in QAS and PRD. We still at the DEV phase.

I attached the error.

Anyone can advise me what is the approach to change the accounting principle for ledger and non leading ledger - the Config ID - 103556

entry.title: Release Navigator for SAP Cloud ERP 2602
entry.content:
Welcome to 2026! As we step into this promising new year, we're excited to introduce the 2602 release. This latest version is packed with innovative features and enhancements designed to optimize your business processes and drive your digital transformation forward.

Our team has been thoroughly reviewing your feedback and working diligently to create new release content specifically for you. Whether you‚Äôre navigating complex software upgrades, synchronizing release schedules, or optimizing project efficiency, these updates are meant to keep you informed about the newest features. In the upcoming 2602 release, we will discover the exciting new content from SAP experts, now at your fingertips.

As of today, content inside the release navigator will begin to be updated to 2602 through February! 

Explore the Product Specific Page

The product-specific page for SAP Cloud ERP serves as a comprehensive resource designed to provide comprehensive insights into aspects of the product. Here you can explore various lines of business, industries, and cross-topics all with tailored content for your unique needs.

The recently added welcome card on the product-specific page of the release navigator is designed to improve the user experience. This visually appealing element makes navigation more enjoyable.

Utilizing the frequently updated release calendar is highly beneficial. It helps you stay informed of the latest updates and feature rollouts, ensuring that you can take full advantage of improvements and enhancements as they become available. Regularly checking the release calendar allows for proactive planning and better alignment with software updates, keeping your operations smooth and up-to-date.

 

SAP Cloud ERP provides numerous advantages, such as real-time data access for quick decision-making and reduced IT costs due to its cloud-based infrastructure. It enables seamless integration across departments, enhancing collaboration and productivity. Additionally, it offers scalability, allowing businesses to grow without hassle, and ensures robust security with regular updates to keep data protected and systems current.

 The product-specific page features convenient tabs that enable you to effortlessly explore various Lines of Business (LOBs), industries, and cross topics. These tabs make it easy to find information and resources that are most relevant to your specific interests and operational requirements.

SAP Cloud ERP supports various Lines of Business (LOB), industries, and cross-functional topics:

  1. Lines of Business: It offers solutions for finance, sales, manufacturing, supply chain management, and more, helping streamline operations and improve efficiency.
  2. Industries: It caters to sectors like retail, education & research, public sector, etc.,   providing industry-specific solutions to address unique challenges and enhance processes.
  1. Cross Topics: SAP Cloud ERP pulls together cross-topics such as sustainability and artificial intelligence, providing tools for actionable data insights, reducing environmental impact, and ensuring compliance with regulations.

entry.title: EWM - update delivery from third party system
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We have a custom supplier portal that currently uses an API to download data from S/4. The portal also has functionality to create / adjust inbound deliveries in S/4 (create, change, delete). For delivery creation, I cannot see any issue - the delivery is created in S/4 and replicated to EWM using standard SAP functionality.

However, the challenge arises with changes or deletions because the S/4 delivery is locked, and I think, these actions should start from EWM.

I tried to explore options for communication with 3PLs, but I only found the standard approach using IDocs for warehouse tasks.

My question is: Is there any standard functionality that allows changing a distributed delivery via some integration method like API or IDoc? Ideally, this would include additional features such as error handling (ie, a backward error in case of a delete request when putaway or completion has already been done).

 

Thank you

Standa

entry.title: Re: Do client computers need to have SQL Anywhere install...
entry.content:
To acually answer the title question:
Client computers do not need to have a full SQL Anywhere install but need to have the required database client files installed. What set of files is required (say ODBC, JDBC, .Net, PHP etc.), depends on the client application that is to be used. Furthermore, if clients should also use SQL Central or Interactive ISQL, this can be added as an "Addministration Tool" deployment.

If the same application is to be used by several client machines, I would recommend to create an appropriate setup via the Deployment Wizard tool.


Here's a starting link:
Requirements for Deploying Client Applications

entry.title: 'Select All' fields option in the Story Report
entry.content:
Currently, when generating a story report, there is no option to select all fields, neither at the Query Designer, nor at the Add Dimensions section for either the Rows or Columns areas. Each field added from the data source must be selected individually (manually) in the Add Dimensions section for it to appear in the report.

There should be a ‚ÄòSelect All‚Äô fields option available at the top of the field selection list within the Query Designer and at Add Dimensions section. This would allow users to select all fields at once when needed, while still preserving the option to manually select/deselect individual fields.

Implementing this functionality would greatly benefit users who create, modify, or enhance Story reports, ultimately improving overall user experience. If you feel the same, I would request you to vote for the customer influence idea:

https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/357089 

#SuccessFactors #StoryReports #Analytics SAP SuccessFactors Platform @Anvesh_Sankoori

entry.title: Re: New or not to the SAP Community, share your story!
entry.content:
Thomas Marx ‚Äì Consulting Director with cbs Corporate Business Solutions ‚Äì leads the global  foreign-trade consulting practice. With the company since 2005 Thomas learned all about SAP Global Trade Services (GTS) since its 7.0 release. As IT-integration of customs- and export-control processes became wide-spread the team grew to a diverse group of experts covering all aspects of foreign trade IT-support. Today, the team claims more than 100 SAP GTS implementations worldwide ‚Äì and is one of the leading SAP GTS consultancies. Thomas established SAP GTS country-focus groups in Switzerland, China and the United States to provide 24/7 support to the SAP GTS community. His career took him around the globe - implementing SAP GTS for both hidden champions and global players in industries such as Mobility, Life Science, Health Care / Pharma, High Tech, Future & Green Tech. His special focus lies with Aerospace&Defense. With almost ten years working in the U.S. he build his expertise in mapping U.S. export control regulations ‚Äì both ITAR and EAR ‚Äì to SAP software. He supports the foreign trade community as a guest lecturer on various occasions and at various institutions.       

Thomas holds a university degree in business administration and ‚Äì together with his family - lives near Heidelberg in the Southwest of Germany. Whenever time allows he can be found in his garden taking care of his bee hives.

entry.title: Deploy Machine Learning Model as Fast API to Cloud Foundry BTP Trial
entry.content:
Deploy Machine Learning Model as Fast API to Cloud Foundry BTP Trial

Objective: This Blog helps an SAP developer who is new to Machine Learning and want to learn how a python machine learning model can be deployed to BTP trial account. 

Later this model api can be consumed to SAP UI5 application.

Project structure was the challenging part for me being an on-prem ABAP consultant  üòÄ with zero knowledge in BTP deployment. 

Note: This model is not an enterprise grade machine learning model. This is a beginner friendly model for learning purpose.

Pre-requisite:

BTP trial account and Business application Studio.

Create Project Structure:

Step 1: Create simple machine learning python program using scikit learn and expose it using FAST API.

My Project structure:

mypython/

|-- app.py                          # FastAPI python code

|-- requirements.txt     # Python Dependencies

|-- Procfile                       # Command for CF(Cloud Foundry) to start the web application

|--manifest.yml           # CF deployment config

 

File 1: app.py

This is a sample python program to create REST API that serves a machine learning model for classifying Iris flowers using The Gaussian Naive Bayes classifier.

 

 

File 2: manifest.yml

 

File 3: Procfile

 

 

File 4: requirement.txt

 

 

 

Local Testing:

Test the program before deployment to cloud foundry.

Click on the app.py file and right-click -> Open in integrated Terminal. Terminal will open with current project directory.

  • Run command pip install -r requirements.txt

Run command to test the fast api locally.

 

Code written is used for running the fast api locally

# Run locally with: app.py

if __name__ == "__main__":

    import uvicorn

    uvicorn.run(app, host="0.0.0.0", port=8000)

 

Hover to the link and click on follow link.

 

 

 

Below links will open.

 

 

Add postfix \docs to test the application in browser.

 

 

Deployment to Cloud Foundry

  • In Business application studio, First login to cloud foundry

Press ctrl+shift+P to login to cloud foundry and login to cloud foundry.

 

  • Push command to final deploy to cloud foundry

 

 

In case deployment is fails logs can be checked by

 cf logs < CF app name e.g. > --recent

 

Check the deployed app in cloud foundry

Go to the sub-account and the dev space where you have deployed the app you can get all the necessary details.

 

 

 

You can click on the api link and check test the api by added \docs postfix.

 

Conclusion:

You got the basic understanding how python api gets deployed to cloud foundry which can consumed by the UI5 or CAP application for integrating it to business application.

Happy Learning!

Reference:

Create an Application with Cloud Foundry Python Buildpack | SAP Tutorials

entry.title: Re: Managing Invoices with SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management
entry.content:
Hello Shama,

Here are few suggestions from my side. Please note that it is basis my understanding. Kindly confirm further. Requesting others also to add more.
Would also request you to confirm back with details once you resolve/settle these queries. It would help others.

Email Notifications: Is there a way to configure email notification to concerned team (Example: Accounts Payable team members) to manually edit invoices with error or insufficient information?

AS > Request for Information Workflow
This allows users to request for additional information about a supplier invoice. The request can be manually sent to one or more recipients.

User Set up: We have limited number of users to be configured for approval workflows or email notification set up. Does this still require connecting CIM under IAS services?
AS > Yes, as per my understanding

Tax Calculation: Our client has either 0% or 10% GST applicable on invoices. While the tax amount is mentioned in invoices, tax rate is not explicitly mentioned. How do we set up business rules based on tax rate in such case?
AS > You would need to arrive at some logic to determine the applicable tax rate irrespective of tax amount mentioned in invoice. Kindly refer this link for more details to form such logic - Configuring a Business Rule to Determine Invoice Taxes

Company code determination: If a supplier is active under 2 company codes, how does invoice determine company code when it flows from email integration method?
AS > Buyer name and address on invoice can be used by CIM logic for matching against the master data that the customer provides as their locations under each company code. Also, PO number on Invoice file can be used to determine right Company code.
May be you can raise a case for more details.
If it is about email bots, only 1 Company Code is supported.
3480192 - How many Company Codes are supported per Email Bot?

Supplier sync: Is there a way to check supplier fields that flow to CIM? Is the supplier description update / supplier block expected to flow to CIM? We are able to check Success / failure logs but not able to see field details.
AS > 'Display Imported Master Data' app can be used to view imported suppliers. However, data shown is limited only. 'Posting Block' field is present here.

entry.title: Global Trade Services - Quo vadis 2026 - Establish your central foreign-trade platform, now
entry.content:
With 2026 bringing us past SAP‚Äôs support deadline for SAP GTS 11.0 and many companies already shifted to the new SAP Global Trade Services edition for SAP HANA, we suggest taking a break and reflecting on the future of cross-border trade. 2025 clearly showed ‚Äì the world and therefore the world of trade changes rapidly and dramatically.

To start, we see a change in perspective by the United States of America that is taught to the world with painstaking explicitness. It seems that imposing tariffs and monetary trade barriers has become acceptable again to reinforce national interests ‚Äì even at the risk of alienating allies and partners. Surprised - the western world watched and tried to adapt only to find that this new style of trade politics seemed to be rather rough-and-ready made - subject to quick change and ‚Äì some suppose ‚Äì garnished with a touch of the irrational.    

Next, there‚Äôs the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, requiring Western nations to invest heavily in defense solutions. Not only to directly support the fighting Ukrainian Forces, but also, in the case of the European Union, to rethink and refurbish their military concept and national defense forces. With this, hybrid threats arise like IT attacks against infrastructure and individual companies. To counter this, the EU economy needs to adhere to gradually stricter embargo situations (i.e., pointed at Russia and Belarus) and sanctions against organizations and individuals. Also, former profitable markets are shut down now, and prices for imported goods, e.g., energy is gnawing away at the competitiveness of entire industries.      

We also see the growing confidence of China as a global super power ‚Äì and we have to realize that ‚Äì with regards to the western dependency - not only on finished / consumer goods and components - but also with regards to raw materials (esp. rare earths) ‚Äì there is no quick way of ‚Äúde-risking‚Äù, i.e. the shift to other supplying countries / trading partners. Although it is, of course, a good approach to look elsewhere; it may well be too little too late. For many, a day when the Western world will not be able to seriously interfere with China‚Äôs plans and ambitions, and the KPC knows that time is running out in its hands.

Finally, for the purpose of this rough picture, there is the search for new allies and partnerships, or it seemed to be like that with players like India, Brazil, and the African countries being focused on and courted. That‚Äôs with high competition, of course, with the EU, the U.S., Russia, and China likewise trying to mark their territory. And since the first days of 2026, it‚Äôs not only wild rhetoric about Greenland or Taiwan, a rougher playground on some smaller islands or the Antarctic or its straightforward intervention securing Venezuela (for its oil) with military power to the U.S. sphere of interest.

Talking of oil, fossil fuels still keep our economies running and, think plastic ‚Äì enable that wide range of products that civilizations consider irreplaceable. But there are other often overlooked ‚Äúcommodities‚Äù ‚Äì e.g., salt, sand, that economies depend upon. Together with the resource problem, there‚Äôs climate change, and with that, there‚Äôs migration and the struggle to keep many of this planet‚Äôs habitats in livable conditions. Environmental compliance is coming at us.

Ok ‚Äì and we haven‚Äôt even paid a closer look to what‚Äôs going on in the Middle East with the Palestine / Gaza conflict, only being the obvious indication of that region‚Äôs structural instability. With powerful players like Turkey and Iran struggling for hegemony. A situation that again imposes restrictions on trade (again one of the more obvious scenarios: e.g., Huthi attacks on merchant vessels) and nothing less but a powder keg for the years to come.

So ‚Äì clearly ‚Äì it‚Äôs gone ‚Äì that post-Cold War vision of a world prospering through global and free trade. The world is moving and changing ‚Äì on the lookout for new stability and leadership.

That being said, what implications do we draw from all of this, both as a company and as the one responsible for foreign trade operations and policies?

There‚Äôs no denying anymore. Customs and Compliance functions are not just necessities to ‚Äúkeep things moving‚Äù. These functions are not ‚Äúin the way‚Äù of a smooth logistics process understood as ‚Äúgetting stuff out of the door ‚Äì or in‚Äù. They are key.

I know ‚Äì lobbying for these functions and attempts to increase their visibility/importance are plentiful, and this song is played at least for all my twenty-plus years of professional career.

But this time, understanding the rules and playing by them, navigating the often-unchartered waters of customs & compliance per country can and will make the future‚Äôs competitive difference. And remember ‚Äì there‚Äôs no outsourcing, as you will always be ultimately responsible for what was declared in your name, so wisely manage your customs brokers / agents and go check that power of attorney ever so often. Why am I pushing this point?

Think about it that way. If countries and nations become more restrictive and in control - trying to monitor and manage the flow of goods into or out of their territory - the customs declaration becomes THE one vehicle to gather all information desired (upfront). This trend is not new ‚Äì  we can see that in the European Union, where Declarants are required to navigate measures and codes of the TARIC or in the U.S., where so-called partnering government agencies ‚Äì of which there are 40+ - may require additional data (e.g., FDA certificates) for certain products/groups. With Tariffs now on the rise, a good and thorough understanding of the catalogue of HS-codes of that jurisdiction is suggested, and be on the watch-out, as we can expect regular changes and additions. With more and more information to provide, changes to consider, and rules to abide by, risk increases. It can range from lapses to faults - but not being in control when declaring to (customs) authorities may draw the external auditor‚Äôs attention ‚Äì reputation, money, and market access may be at stake. Depending on whether your company is a truly global player, follows a multi-national or international, i.e., more centralized approach, you may face several challenges:

  • Rapid change: sanctions, embargoes, and product-restrictions may become effective quite quickly, as do new Tariff rates.
  • Antagonist regulations: You may find e.g. business partners being sanctioned in one part of the world but ok in another (e.g., Huawei, Kharon). The same applies to embargoes and country-of-origin-based rules
  • More complex regulations: Think about the duty of built-in aluminum, in addition to the end-product‚Äôs HS codes Tariff rate. Or how about BIS 50% Rule? Or China‚Äôs export control regulations mimicking the ‚Äúde minimis‚Äù concept.
  • Additional and enhanced regulations: Think about the EU green deal, CBAM, deforestation, etc. It will not only affect supply chains, it will also come down to an operational level at e.g. the time of the customs declaration.
  • Many design options: Think free-trade agreements. You may want to take advantage of many FTAs following the same-same but different rules and geopolitical concepts (e.g., USMCA, RCEP, etc.). That‚Äôs also true for customs procedures (FreeTradeZones, in-/outward processing, bonded and transit procedures), which can be used to support a corporate supply chain concept and increase efficiency.
  • Regional destabilization: It‚Äôs not only about open conflict ‚Äì we may see equivalents or recall of decisions like the BREXIT, depending on political majorities.

To mitigate all this and remain ahead of the game, it is non-negotiable to resort to a software solution that can serve as a truly global platform for all things in foreign trade. And yes ‚Äì that‚Äôs SAP Global Trade Services (GTS).

That's new to you ? - Check out the posts by @Trond  and @T_Frenehard.  

Besides all flaws that critics love to identify, denying the fact that we are talking about standard-software designed to be fit-for-purpose, no matter what your product/services are. SAP GTS is designed to serve customs and compliance processes all over the world. I myself have implemented SAP GTS in industries as diverse as e.g., food & beverages vs. aerospace & defense. But why am I advocating a central foreign trade IT platform?

  • It‚Äôs global by design

SAP GTS is a separate system, and that‚Äôs for a reason. You can connect as many SAP- or non-SAP ‚Äúfeeder systems‚Äù as you like, making sure everything foreign trade converges here. While within GTS ‚Äì with a proper design of your roles & authorizations ‚Äì you can make sure that data is routed to the correct process and the right person in charge.

  • It is modular and roll-out ready

There‚Äôs no GTS big-bang. You can implement the four services (Compliance Management, Customs Management, Risk Management, and Electronic Compliance Reporting) per country, as you see fit. So, the organization can grow from concentrating on the markets with much cross-border trade to those growing or following an overall SAP implementation strategy.

  • It supports the organization

It is one thing to have an IT tool in place supporting customs compliance. However, what‚Äôs crucial is to have a team of experts working with the system. By looking ‚Äúat the same thing,‚Äù your customs and compliance experts can learn from and with each other ‚Äì and discuss supply chain design across borders (think intercompany processing, sanction party screening (do you read Chinese?), etc.). With the same tool and the same information available, your team is free to level up the quality of their collaborative work to ensure customs compliance.

  • It is standard

People understand it ‚Äì and you can find GTS employees already in the market. Many times, a process is designed and pre-configured, and many features e.g. electronic data exchange with national customs authorities, are readily available out of the box for many countries.

  • It is supported

With over 20 years in the market, SAP GTS has grown, matured, and today sets the standard for IT-supported foreign trade platforms. As global companies ‚Äì the customers of SAP ‚Äì cannot operate in national markets alone, customers of SAP can be sure that GTS will be supported and enhanced as an essential product in SAP‚ÄôS Governance, Risk and Compliance (GRC) portfolio.

  • It is integrative

As part of the ‚ÄúSAP family,‚Äù SAP GTS ‚Äúunderstands many of the processes and complex scenarios you can map with SAP‚ÄôS ERP solutions (e.g. S/4HANA). That means remarkable freedom of design is given to map complex scenarios (e.g. shipments of configurable material, repair processes with third-party service providers, etc.)

  • It is open

You can connect third-party data providers to load sanctioned party lists, duty rates, HScodes, ECCNs, and other data to ensure up-to-date quality. Using the ‚Äúbroker interface,‚Äù a customs broker can be directly connected to GTS to support accurate data transfer and compliance. Also, e.g. via SAP BTP, clever bespoke solutions to support, e.g. EU entry certificates can be implemented.

  • It can be encapsulated

SAP GTS services can be deployed and provided as desired per jurisdiction. That means if, within a company, different design ideas exist about e.g., how strictly the export control process or the assignment  of HS codes should be handled (think ‚Äúnational eyes only‚Äù, 4-eyes-principle, workflows, etc.), these functionalities can be provided to the national customs and compliance teams exactly the way they desire it. This also enables you to have services exclusively for a national team (e.g., ITAR compliance).  

Still, the initial question ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs next‚Äù with SAP GTS is with us for 2026. While SAP provides regular releases every two years for GTS edition for SAP HANA, I would like to suggest not only looking at this foreign trade platform based on SAP‚Äôs product-development-roadmap alone. The growing importance of mastering and managing foreign trade processes should be mapped into a global roll-out plan based on a thorough business analysis. Where do we sell to and from where are we selling? Where does the highest volume of cross-border shipments happen? Are there any critical processes or products (e.g., with military application, subject to U.S. (or soon Chinese) re-export control, etc.)? It is essential that ‚Äì in this phase ‚Äì desired functionality is described by the business WITHOUT looking at SAP GTS‚Äô standard capabilities.      

Assume SAP GTS as an open platform ‚Äì some features are not (yet) provided by SAP standard, but there are many good and compatible solutions in the market to improve the solution according to your (industry‚Äôs) specific needs. To list a few: AI-based selection/assignment of ECCNs/HS codes, solutions to manage country-of-origin information, machine-read interpretation of incoming documents, like e.g. long-term-supplier-declarations, ‚Ä¶. Follow the idea of a ‚Äúpain-point-killer‚Äù to free potential today tied up in repetitive and tedious work.

Reporting and KPIs ‚Äì often asked for and seldom defined. With SAP Analytics now built into GTS, and the option to connect SAP BI think about setting up a corporate reporting tool to provide information in a corporate standard ‚Äì strengthening the value proposition of customs & compliance management within your company.

Follow your IT strategy. When rolling out anyway or within the waves of SAP S/4 implementations, make sure foreign trade processing is not forgotten or overlooked. Happens to often that while redefining logistics in a greenfield approach or mapping the existing process landscape for a brownfield conversion, cross-border process examples are not considered until the test phase. To the great joy of both IT and business. But if considered from the very beginning of an S/4 initiative, it is an interesting leverage for customs & compliance participating in your SAP conversion/roll-out projects.    

Turn it into an opportunity. All the changes from a rather free-trade-minded world-order to a more nationalist and block-mindedness also offer new opportunities for trade relations. Make sure you review your customs procedures in place and you identify where customs and compliance may help make a substantial difference to build a global supply chain (e.g. review of sourcing countries, usage of credit-function and exterritorial status of certain customs procedures, implement GTS to markets with now increasing volume of shipments, complement and integrate mayor production sites into your SAP (GTS) landscape. Follow the progress of national customs/compliance authorities to IT support your trade operations early (e.g. China Single Window).

Seek a high degree of automatization (e.g., HS code assignment, Customs and PGA code assignment, document processing, FI-integration, etc.). Yes ‚Äì there‚Äôs no fail-proof system and yes, responsibility remains with you; however, give room to the thought that humans also made errors and rethink/evaluate the realistic threat vs. a much quicker and more streamlined IT solution, which ‚Äì supported by artificial intelligence ‚Äì will improve more and more over time.

Understand your role not as the hunted in a growing jungle of rules and regulations ‚Äì always with one foot in jail ‚Äì but be the designer of a powerful solution that frees you and your customs and compliance team to navigate your business through challenging times. 2026 ‚Äì any time after your GTSe4H upgrade - is just the right moment to begin!

entry.title: Bin Location Content List shows quantity in source bin after bin-to-bin transfer in SAP Business One
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

I need some clarification on a behavior observed in SAP Business One related to bin-managed warehouses.

Scenario

In a bin-managed warehouse, the Bin Location Content List report continues to show quantity in the source bin even after the stock has been transferred to another bin. I understand this could be standard SAP behavior, but I would like to understand the underlying logic and whether any workaround is available.

Steps to reproduce the issue:

  1. Create a Goods Receipt PO into Warehouse 1 and assign the stock to ABC bin.

  2. Perform a bin-to-bin transfer from ABC bin to XYZ bin.

  3. Run the Bin Location Content List report for the same item.

Actual result:

The quantity is still displayed in the ABC bin in the Bin Location Content List.

Expected result:

The quantity in ABC bin should be zero or no longer displayed, as the stock has already been transferred to XYZ bin.

Questions:

  • Is this behavior by design in SAP Business One?

  • What is the technical or functional reason for the quantity still appearing in the source bin?

  • Is there any recommended workaround or alternative report to reflect the real-time bin balance correctly?

  • Are there any specific settings, refresh logic, or known SAP Notes related to this behavior?

Any insights or best practices from SAP consultants or experts would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance for your support.

Best regards,

Sunil Patil

Certified SAP Business One Consultant

entry.title: Get Ready for 2602 Upgrade of SAP Cloud ERP Public Edition
entry.content:
Introduction

During this weekend of Jan. 17-18, we can see the T system to be upgraded to 2602 of SAP Cloud ERP Public Edition, and D and P systems in four weeks during February 14-15. This blog intends to do a quick highlight of what has changed since 2408 Upgrade.  The content is limited to CBC Based 3 System Landscape.

 

Highlights of 2602 Upgrade

Shortened Major Upgrade Window (UMW)

From 2408 Upgrade, SAP operations team was able to reduce the UMW from 24 to 8 hours.  This reduction trend keeps going on: from 2508 Upgrade, the UMW has been further reduced to 4 hours.  The 2602 Upgrade will be the same.

In the below Downtime Window picture, the P system upgrade starts from 01:00 UTC on Sunday. That is 20:00 EST on Saturday. By midnight of New York time, the upgrade ends.  Therefore, the customer has an entire Sunday to perform post-upgrade tasks.

Downtime Window for SAP Cloud ERP Public Edition 2602 Upgrade

Below picture have a clear illustration about the upgrade process for the D and T systems.  If you want to learn more about the upgrade process, I have a good explanation in my blog Understand Upgrading and Patching Processes of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Detailed Upgrade Process for the D and T systems

 

What to Test after T System Upgrade

There is a wrong conception that after T system upgrade, the customers will conduct testing on new features and functions. I happen to run into a picture giving a good explanation on this topic.  As illustrated in the below slide, even after upgrade to 2608, T-system still has 2508 content; therefore, no new features or functions are available for testing. Rather, you use this system to test out what is working up to now in the old release content (2508) but in the new system (2602). 

T-System Still Contains 2508 Content after 2602 Upgrade

The 2602 Content becomes available after the D-System is upgraded, and a new transport is created and becomes available to deliver the 2602 Content to the T-System.  See the illustration in below picture.

T-System Content Is Upgraded to 2602 with a Transport from D-System after Its Upgrade

 

Transports Aging Issue

This is not a new topic, but worth highlighting again. For the compatibility concern, transports follow N+1 rule.  This N is related with major upgrades like 2602.  For example, if you created many transports on a 2502 system, they need to be moved to P-System before 2602 upgrade. Otherwise, they are aged to be N+2.  The 2602 T and P systems won‚Äôt accept them.  In comparison, any transports created on a 2508 system, i.e., current release, have no problem to be imported into T and P systems after upgrading to 2602 release.

 

Key Dates of 2602 Upgrade

With the 2602 Upgrade going on, we should keep the following key dates in mind:

  • January 14 is the last day to request and provision 2508 T system.
  • From January 14, all new systems requested/provisioned are in 2602 release.  D and P systems will be in the same version.
  • January 17-18 is for T system upgrade
  • January 31 ‚Äì February 1 is for Starter, Parter TDD and sandbox system upgrade.
  • February 14-15 is for D and P system upgrades.

 

References

  • My Blog: Understand Upgrading and Patching Processes of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • My Blog: FAQ on Upgrading SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, 3-System Landscape Upgrade & Maintenance Schedule (December 5, 2025)
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Software Lifecycle Management for Customers (September 3, 2025)

entry.title: How to set a default long text for items via F0798 billing document creation
entry.content:
My client has currently some custom code in an implicit enhancement of dynpro in VF01 (billing document creation) which automatically assigns a calculated long text to some items, instead of copying the texts from the sales order to the billing document.

For information, this text is dynamically determined via a complex program logic and cannot be defined by the standard text functions (VOTXN).

The custom code stores the long text in the tables STXH/STXL (TDOBJECT = "VBBP", TDID = "ZXXX", TDNAME = "billing document number / item number").

The custom code is obviously not triggered when using the Fiori App F0798, because it's called only for the dynpro technology.

How to do the same custom code for the Fiori App?

Thanks.

Sandra

entry.title: Re: How to set a default long text for items via F0798 billing document creation
entry.content:
First of all, here's the general logic of VF01 and F0798, with focus on the long texts.

With VF01, a document numbered $000000001 is created in memory and shown. When saving it, it's created in the database with the final number (e.g. number 10000755).

With F0798, when the user selects a sales order and clicks "create billing document", CL_SD_BIL_SNAPSHOT_FACADE=>IF_SD_BIL_DRADOC_ACTION~CREATE is called which creates a draft billing document in the database with a TMP number (e.g. number TMP0000001). The draft document is then shown in the Fiori App.

Internally, the draft document is created in 2 steps by calling two function modules:

  • RV_INVOICE_CREATE calculates the document and stores it in memory with a dollar number (e.g. $000000001):
    • The text buffer is cleared (DELETE_TEXT_FROM_CATALOG)
    • The copy texts are initialized (RV_TEXT_COPY, which calls SAVE_TEXT)
  • RV_INVOICE_DOCUMENT_ADD renumbers the dollar document into a temporary document and saves it to the database. Here's the logic:
    • The document number is changed from e.g. $000000001 to TMP0000001
    • The texts are also renumbered by RV_TEXT_RENAME (which calls RENAME_TEXT_ARRAY)
    • It calls the user exit subroutine USEREXIT_SAVE_DOCUMENT_PREPARE of SAPLV60A, which is to be created in RV60AFZZ, as explained in 1831486 - Use of form routine USEREXIT_SAVE_DOCUMENT_PREPARE - SAP for Me. This user exit is called once per document (*), the document is in the header line XVBRK, XVBRK-VBELN contains the new document number (never "$"), the XVBRP lines continue to have VBELN = the old number "$...", the variable BELEG = the old number "$..." from XVBRK-VBELN.
    • The function module SD_COMMIT_TEXT is called, which calls COMMIT_TEXT, which calls HANDLE_TEXT_ARRAY_AFTER_COMMIT in the update task to insert the texts into the tables STXH and STXL
    • RV_INVOICE_POST is called in the update task to save to the database:
      • The temporary document is saved into the database (as draft VBRK-DRAFT = "X"; and also VBRK-RFBSK = "D" / not relevant for accounting).

When the user clicks "save" on the draft document (e.g. TMP0000001), CL_SD_BIL_SNAPSHOT_FACADE=>IF_SD_BIL_DRADOC_ACTION~ACTIVATE is called:

Internally, the same function modules are called with few changes:

  • RV_INVOICE_CREATE calculates a new billing document in the memory with a new dollar number (e.g. $000000002).
    • The copy texts are also initialized (RV_TEXT_COPY, which calls SAVE_TEXT)
    • The text buffer is cleared (DELETE_TEXT_FROM_CATALOG)
  • RV_INVOICE_DOCUMENT_ADD renumbers the dollar document into the final document and saves it to the database. Here's the logic:
    • The document number is changed from e.g. $000000002 to 0010000755
    • The texts are also renumbered by RV_TEXT_RENAME (which calls RENAME_TEXT_ARRAY)
    • It calls the user exit subroutine USEREXIT_SAVE_DOCUMENT_PREPARE of SAPLV60A, all the remarks above are still valid, but with the difference that it's called twice, once for the draft document (previously processed) and once for the final document. One can test that BELEG starts with "$" to process only the new document.
    • The function module SD_COMMIT_TEXT is called, which calls COMMIT_TEXT, which calls HANDLE_TEXT_ARRAY_AFTER_COMMIT in the update task to insert the texts into the tables STXH and STXL
    • RV_INVOICE_POST is called in the update task to save to the database:
      • The final document in VBRK has DRAFT = " " and RFBSK is different from "D" ("A" in my case)
      • The temporary document is deleted. NB: it's possible that several temporary documents exist for the same original sales order, all of them are deleted at once.

Solution:

To initialize a long text by full custom code, implement USEREXIT_SAVE_DOCUMENT_PREPARE as follows:

  • Do the logic only if BELEG(1) = '$' (we're currently turning the draft document into the final billing document, no need to reprocess the draft document).
  • For each line of XVBRP having VBELN = BELEG (final document with the dollar number).
    • Call INIT_TEXT with TDOBJECT = 'VBBP', TDID = 'ZXXX' and TDNAME = concatenation of XVBRK-VBELN (final number e.g. "0010000755") and XVBRP-POSNR.
    • Call SAVE_TEXT with INSERT = 'X', SAVEMODE_DIRECT = ' ' and LINES = the text to save.

Sandra

PS: the answer is valid for S/4HANA 2023 FPS 01

entry.title: Using SAP UI5 & Public API to Build a Sudoku Game ‚Äì A Learning Experiment
entry.content:
Application Approach
I followed the standard MVC structure in UI5.
The view displays a 9√ó9 Sudoku grid using sap.m.Input controls, while the controller manages the API calls, timer logic, and input validation.
Instead of introducing additional abstraction early on, I handled the Sudoku grid and game state directly inside the controller. Prefilled cells are rendered as non-editable, and empty cells accept user input.
Integrating the Sudoku API
The Sudoku puzzle is fetched from a public API when the application starts or when the user chooses to begin a new game. The API response is processed and the values are assigned to the corresponding input fields in the grid.
Initially, I noticed some UI flickering when updating values. This was caused by updating inputs multiple times inside a loop. After restructuring the logic to update each cell only once, the UI behavior became much smoother.
Timer Implementation
To make the game more engaging, I added a simple timer. The timer starts when the puzzle is loaded. Managing the timer inside a UI5 application helped me understand how asynchronous logic works alongside UI events.
Final Thoughts
This Sudoku game started as a small experiment but turned into a useful learning project. It showed me that SAP UI5 is flexible enough to handle interactive applications with real-time feedback.
I plan to continue improving it by refining the validation logic and adding small usability improvements as I keep learning UI5.
controller.js

sap.ui.define([
    "sap/ui/core/mvc/Controller",
    "sap/m/Input",
    "sap/m/HBox",
    "sap/m/VBox",
    "sap/ui/core/HTML"
], (Controller, Input, HBox, VBox, HTML) => {
    "use strict";

    return Controller.extend("com.sudokuapi.controller.App", {
        timer: null,
        seconds: 0,
        cells: [],

        onInit() {
            this.onNewGame();
        },

        /* =================== NEW GAME =================== */
        onNewGame: function () {
            this.resetTimer();
            this.startTimer();

            fetch("https://sugoku.onrender.com/board?difficulty=easy")
                .then(r => r.json())
                .then(d => this.buildGrid(d.board));
        },

        /* =================== TIMER =================== */
        startTimer: function () {
            if (this.timer) clearInterval(this.timer);

            this.timer = setInterval(() => {
                this.seconds++;
                this.updateTimerText();
            }, 1000);
        },

        resetTimer: function () {
            this.seconds = 0;
            this.updateTimerText();
        },

        updateTimerText: function () {
            const m = String(Math.floor(this.seconds / 60)).padStart(2, "0");
            const s = String(this.seconds % 60).padStart(2, "0");
            this.byId("timerText").setText(`Time: ${m}:${s}`);
        },

        /* =================== GRID =================== */
        buildGrid: function (board) {
            const oBox = this.byId("sudokuGridInner") || document.getElementById("sudokuGridInner");
            oBox.innerHTML = ""; // Clear old grid
            this.cells = [];

            for (let r = 0; r < 9; r++) {
                const rowDiv = document.createElement("div");
                rowDiv.className = "sudokuRow";
                this.cells[r] = [];

                for (let c = 0; c < 9; c++) {
                    const isFixed = board[r][c] !== 0;
                    const input = document.createElement("input");
                    input.type = "number";
                    input.maxLength = 1;
                    input.value = isFixed ? board[r][c] : "";
                    input.disabled = isFixed;
                    input.className = "sudokuCell";
                    input.dataset.row = r;
                    input.dataset.col = c;

                    // Live validation
                    input.addEventListener("input", () => {
                        this.validateCell(r, c);
                    });

                    this.cells[r][c] = input;
                    rowDiv.appendChild(input);
                }

                oBox.appendChild(rowDiv);
            }
        },

        /* =================== VALIDATION =================== */
        onCheckSolution: function () {
            for (let r = 0; r < 9; r++) {
                for (let c = 0; c < 9; c++) {
                    this.validateCell(r, c, true); // force full check
                }
            }
        },

        validateCell: function (row, col, force = false) {
            const input = this.cells[row][col];
            if (!input || input.disabled) return;

            const val = parseInt(input.value, 10);
            let isValid = true;

            if (isNaN(val) || val < 1 || val > 9) {
                isValid = false;
            } else {
                // Check row
                for (let c = 0; c < 9; c++) {
                    if (c !== col && parseInt(this.cells[row][c].value, 10) === val) {
                        isValid = false;
                        break;
                    }
                }
                // Check column
                for (let r = 0; r < 9; r++) {
                    if (r !== row && parseInt(this.cells[r][col].value, 10) === val) {
                        isValid = false;
                        break;
                    }
                }
                // Check 3x3 box
                const startRow = Math.floor(row / 3) * 3;
                const startCol = Math.floor(col / 3) * 3;
                for (let r2 = startRow; r2 < startRow + 3; r2++) {
                    for (let c2 = startCol; c2 < startCol + 3; c2++) {
                        if ((r2 !== row || c2 !== col) &&
                            parseInt(this.cells[r2][c2].value, 10) === val) {
                            isValid = false;
                        }
                    }
                }
            }

            input.style.backgroundColor = isValid ? "white" : "lightcoral";
        }
    });
});

view.xml

<mvc:View
    controllerName="com.sudokuapi.controller.App"
    xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
    xmlns="sap.m"
    xmlns:core="sap.ui.core">
  
  <App>
    <pages>
      <Page title="Sudoku">
        <content>
          <VBox alignItems="Center" width="100%">
            <Text id="timerText" text="Time: 00:00" class="sapUiMediumMargin"/>
            
            <!-- Use escaped HTML inside core:HTML -->
            <core:HTML
                id="sudokuGrid"
                content="<div id='sudokuGridInner' class='sudokuGrid'></div>" />
            
            <HBox justifyContent="Center" class="sapUiMediumMarginTop">
              <Button text="New Game" press="onNewGame" />
              <Button text="Check Solution" press="onCheckSolution" class="sapUiMediumMarginBegin"/>
            </HBox>
          </VBox>
        </content>
      </Page>
    </pages>
  </App>
</mvc:View>

output

Thank you!!

entry.title: Re: Setting the Default Kerberos Credential in MacBook Credential Cache
entry.content:
Although also somewhat off-topic wrt. this blog above, I'll mention that in the case of various Desktop Linux computers or VMs, where those machines are connected to an organisation network, you can authenticate to an AD server with some config file adjustments and then in a Terminal getting the relevant ADuser@REALM Kerberos Token into local cache. The steps are described in a blog I wrote in 2025 (obviously in the Linux part of the blog):

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/enabling-ad-based-kerberos-for-windows-macbook-and-desktop-linux/ba-p/14228175 

So that is convenient for SSO from a browser on Ubuntu or other distros to some websites that offer AD-based Kerberos as a login method... however, so far SAP hasn't released any SAP Secure Login Client for Linux, so that's why the only way to SSO for SAPGUI on a Linux distro involves a non-Kerberos setup based on X.509 certificates etcetera.... more details on this approach are in three blogs I wrote in 2023, which are considering (respectively) the Linux, MacBook, and Windows paradigms:

https://community.sap.com/t5/devops-and-system-administration-blog-posts/setting-up-sapgui-sso-on-a-linux-client/ba-p/13560793

https://community.sap.com/t5/devops-and-system-administration-blog-posts/sapgui-encryption-and-sso-with-pses-and-keychain-for-macbooks-amd64-or/ba-p/13550769

https://community.sap.com/t5/devops-and-system-administration-blog-posts/snc-encryption-and-sso-for-sapgui-on-windows-11-via-pse-method-and-slc/ba-p/13556742 

However, scaling out and maintaining these kind of solutions can be quite difficult, which is why many people (including me) prefer the Kerberos-based solutions where possible.

entry.title: Optimizing Your Sales Pipeline with Lead and Opportunity Management
entry.content:
A healthy sales pipeline doesn‚Äôt happen by chance. It‚Äôs built through clear processes, consistent execution, and the ability to focus on the right deals at the right time. For organizations selling across multiple countries and regions, local requirements matter just as much as sales fundamentals; formats for addresses and phone numbers, local languages, currencies, and data privacy obligations can all impact lead quality, conversion, and forecast reliability.

To support sales teams in achieving this, SAP Sales Cloud provides powerful capabilities for managing leads and opportunities across the entire sales cycle, from initial capture to deal closure and forecasting, while accommodating regional requirements. Features such as multi-language user interfaces, localized date/number/currency formats, country-specific address validation, territory and org structures, and consent capture help global teams operate consistently without losing local compliance and context.

The learning asset ‚ÄúOptimizing the Sales Pipeline through Lead and Opportunity Management‚Äù guides you through the core concepts and best practices that help sales teams work more efficiently and make smarter decisions.

In this asset, you‚Äôll learn how to:

  • Structure and manage leads to improve qualification and conversion.
  • Prioritize opportunities using guided selling and intelligent insights.
  • Gain better visibility into pipeline health and forecast accuracy.
  • Support consistent execution across sales teams.

For multinational sales organizations, consider these practical localization tips as you apply the learning:

  • Standardize lead intake with country-aware formats (names, addresses, phone) and enable de-duplication that respects local variations.
  • Localize guided selling content and playbooks to reflect local buying processes, languages, and regulations.
  • Calibrate lead and opportunity scoring with region-specific data so models remain relevant across markets.
  • Configure currencies and exchange rates to ensure pipeline and forecasts reflect local deal values with accurate group-level rollups.
  • Capture and manage consent according to regional data protection laws (for example, opt-in and retention policies), and avoid storing unnecessary personal data.
  • Harmonize stage definitions and forecasting categories globally, while allowing approved local adaptations that preserve comparability.

Access and Requirements:

  • Access link: Optimizing the Sales Pipeline through Lead and Opportunity Management.
  • Prerequisites: A valid S-user ID and an active SAP Enterprise Support subscription are required to access the content.

Whether you‚Äôre looking to improve pipeline quality, increase win rates, or strengthen forecasting confidence, this learning provides practical guidance to help you get more value from SAP Sales Cloud, at global scale and with local precision.

Want to know more?

Explore the SAP CX Value Map combines expert-led guidance with self-paced learning materials:

  • Blogs and Articles ‚Äì Stay up to date with the latest enablement stories, tips, and insights from SAP experts.
  • Event Calendar ‚Äì Join live sessions, webinars, and workshops designed to help you learn directly from specialists.
  • Learning Journeys ‚Äì Build your skills step-by-step through structured, role-based learning.
  • Best Practices and Guides ‚Äì Access ready-to-use materials that simplify complex CX topics.
  • Continuous Quality Check (CQC) Services ‚Äì Keep your SAP CX systems running efficiently.
 
About the author: 

Edmar Rodr√≠guez is a Topic Expert for SAP Enterprise Support value maps, specializing in SAP Customer Experience. With 12 years of experience at SAP and a background spanning roles in various customer support positions, Edmar is passionate about helping customers succeed through SAP Enterprise Support offerings.

entry.title: Release Navigator for Supply Chain Management - What's New in 2602
entry.content:
Welcome to the 2026 Supply Chain Management Community!

We‚Äôre excited to share the latest enhancements coming to the Release Navigator for Supply Chain Management, including new enablement content and expanded product coverage. Our newest update occur over the next few weeks, finalizing on February 20, 2026, bringing you fresh resources designed to help you get the most value from each release.

 

Tool Overview

The Release Navigator for Supply Chain Management, provided through SAP Enterprise Support, is your central hub for understanding and managing new software releases across the supply chain portfolio.

This resource enables you to:

  • Easily explore release content through an organized, intuitive interface.
  • Quickly locate relevant materials, including updates, tools, and documentation for your SAP solutions.
  • Access guided enablement, such as webinars, workshops, and training modules, to help you fully adopt new features and meet your operational goals.

We welcome your ideas for future enhancements‚Äîshare your suggestions using our brief, anonymous two‚Äëquestion survey.

 

New Products

With the 2602 update, we‚Äôre pleased to introduce SAP Logistics Management into the Release Navigator.

SAP Logistics Management is a cloud-based logistics solution that unifies warehouse and transportation management to streamline operations through network‚Äëcentric collaboration. entry.title: Re: Mass Download Of Attachment In SAP Document / Invoice - SAP S4HANA / FICO
entry.content:
Great question, and an important distinction to call out.

The approach described here (using SRGBTBREL + SO tables and GUI_DOWNLOAD*) works very well for S/4HANA On‚ÄëPremise and Private Cloud systems where GOS / SAPoffice attachments are still used and direct backend access is available.

For S/4HANA Cloud (Public Edition) or scenarios where attachments are stored in SAP Document Management Service (DMS) on BTP, this approach would not apply directly due to:
‚Ä¢ No access to SO* tables
‚Ä¢ No GUI_DOWNLOAD
‚Ä¢ Strict API‚Äëbased access only

In Cloud/DMS cases, mass download typically requires:
‚Ä¢ DMS APIs / CMIS APIs
‚Ä¢ SAP BTP-based extraction tools
‚Ä¢ Or controlled exports via Integration Suite

So in summary:
‚úîÔ∏è Best suited for On‚ÄëPrem / Private Cloud with GOS
‚ùå Not directly applicable for Public Cloud / DMS‚Äëonly landscapes

It would be interesting to see a Part‚Äë2 covering DMS‚Äëbased mass extraction patterns on BTP ‚Äî that‚Äôs an area many customers struggle with today.

entry.title: Re: Attachment issue in Delivery
entry.content: Writing the PDF to TOAAT alone is not sufficient for Delivery attachments. GOS visibility requires a valid SRGBTBREL entry for BUS2032 (Delivery) with correct VBELN formatting (ALPHA) and RELTYPE = ATTA. If the attachment appears via manual GOS upload, the repository setup is fine and the issue is the missing GOS linkage in code. Using CL_BINARY_RELATION=>CREATE_LINK or ARCHIV_CONNECTION_INSERT during upload usually resolves this.

entry.title: Re: Clarification about storage path- GOS_ATTACHMENT_LIST...
entry.content: +1 to this. In non‚Äëcontent server setups, SOFFCONT1 is the table that actually stores the binary data for GOS attachments. SRGBTBREL only maintains the business object link, while SOOD/SOFM hold header and metadata. Storage growth is usually driven silently by SOFFCONT1, so checking its size in DB02 is the right first step before any cleanup.
